data.title: People and Positions: Frmr Netscape CEO Joins Sun's Board. Shor Wins Genius Award, $290K. Nascenzi Named CEO of Claritas.
data.meta_description: SHORT TAKES FORMER NETSCAPE CEO JOINS SUN’S BOARD Palo Alto, CA — Sun Microsystems Inc., a maker of workstations, network servers and software, said that Jim Barksdale, the former chief […]
data.text:
SHORT TAKES

FORMER NETSCAPE CEO JOINS SUN’S BOARD

Palo Alto, CA — Sun Microsystems Inc., a maker of workstations, network servers and software, said that Jim Barksdale, the former chief executive of Netscape Communications Corp., has joined its board of directors. Netscape was purchased by America Online Inc. in a three-way deal that was completed in March. As part of the deal, AOL teamed up with Sun to develop and market the Internet software products developed by Netscape. Sun also is selling servers to AOL in a multi-year deal.

Barksdale, 56, is now the managing partner of the Barksdale Group, an investment and advisory group focused exclusively on Internet software and services start-ups. Its first investment was in HomeGrocer.com, an online grocery shopping and delivery service.

QUANTUM COMPUTING THEORIST SHOR WINS GENIUS AWARD

San Diego, CA — Peter Shor, one of the most acclaimed theorists in the field of quantum computing, and a computer scientist at AT&T Research Labs, won a prestigious grant from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. The MacArthur Foundation grants, widely known as the “genius awards,” are large sums of money given to individuals in the hopes that the cash stipend will free them up to continue what the Foundation deems as exceptional work. Shor was awarded $290,000 and cited for his “discoveries [as a computer scientist] that are increasing the speed of some calculations.”

Shor is well known in quantum computing for his theories that proposed what are known as quantum error correction schemes. The main problem with quantum computing was the tendency of passing atoms to interact with and interfere with qubits, thus leading to the notion of quantum computing’s fragility and propensity toward errors. Scientists believe that there is now no known way to avoid these errors, so researchers set out to find theoretical approaches toward quantum computing error correction. –courtesy of Ed Rosenfeld, EIntelligence http://www.eintelligence.com/

NASCENZI NAMED CEO OF CLARITAS

San Diego, CA — Recently Gerald S. Hobbs, CEO of VNU Marketing Information Services (VNU MIS), announced the joining of two VNU MIS divisions: National Decision Systems (NDS) and Claritas Inc. With this change, NDS becomes an operating division of Claritas. Concurrent with the announcement, Robert Nascenzi has been named president and CEO of Claritas.

Robert Nascenzi has been with NDS since 1989 and served as president for the past two years. During that time, he secured NDS’ position as a leader in traditionally site-based businesses, such as the retail and restaurant industries, by introducing a new and highly successful internet/intranet product line imark. He also launched the leading geo-demographic destination site on the web sitereports.com

QLOGIC NAMES CARTER TO BOARD

Costa Mesa, CA — QLogic Corporation a designer of advanced, high-performance I/O controllers for direct connect and storage network interfaces, announced that Larry R. Carter has been appointed to its board of directors.

Carter is currently Sr. Vice President of Finance and Administration and Chief Financial Officer of Cisco Systems, Inc. He has been with Cisco Systems, Inc. since January, 1995. Before joining Cisco, he served as Vice President and Corporate Controller of Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. for two and one-half years. Mr. Carter has served as Chief Financial Officer for VLSI Technology, Inc. and for SGS Thompson Microelectronics, Inc. Prior to those positions, Carter spent 19 years at Motorola, Inc., where he held a variety of financial positions, most recently as Vice President and Controller of the MOS Group.

ADAPTEC NAMES SCHULTZ COO

Milpitas, CA — Adaptec, Inc. announced that Robert Schultz has joined the company as chief operating officer. Schultz joins Adaptec from Compaq Computer Corp. where he most recently held the position of vice president, Server Storage Business Unit, Storage Products Division. Schultz will oversee the product planning, marketing and engineering of the host I/O, RAID and software business units and will report to Bob Stephens, president and CEO.

“Bob brings to Adaptec a fresh perspective and a deep understanding of the systems partners, customer environment and end user needs. We are delighted to have him on board,” stated Bob Stephens, Adaptec’s president and CEO. “With his vast knowledge and experience in the server storage business, his contributions will play a vital role in the future growth of Adaptec.”

EDS NAMES FREDERICK EXEC VP, U.S. OPERATIONS’

Plano, TX — EDS named Douglas Frederick executive vice president, United States operations. Frederick, who joins EDS from Baan Company in The Netherlands, was key architect of the Boeing Co.’s highly successful business-process reengineering project.

Frederick, 49, will be responsible in this newly created position for all sales, delivery services and relationship management for EDS’ U.S.-based clients, excluding General Motors. He will focus on improving growth and performance in the United States and will report directly to President and Chief Operating Officer Jeff Heller.

TORRENT APPTS NEW DIRECTOR OF ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY

Cambridge, MA — Torrent Systems, Inc., announced that Gerard Vichniac has joined Torrent as Director of Advanced Technology. Vichniac brings more than fifteen years of experience in the business of parallel computing and data mining algorithms and has world-class background in physics and mathematics.

Vichniac previously served at two parallel computer firms, Mercury Computer System and Kendall Square Research (KSR), where he held the positions of product manager and senior scientist, respectively. He was a key technical marketing contributor during Mercury’s growth from a $42 million to a $100 million company. Prior to his work at KSR, Vichniac performed research on parallel computing at Cadex Supercomputation and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He was also a network analyst at BBN Communications Corporation, the original builder of the Internet.

— This file compiled by Steve Fisher, HPCwire managing editor. Email: [email protected]
